['Decline - to become less or fall away gradually, often referring to quantities or values.', 'Descend - to move downward, like falling due from high places.', 'Deteriorate - to worsen in quality over time and eventually accumulate damage.', 'Diminish - to reduce in size, amount, or degree until it becomes insignificant.', 'Ebb - the movement of tides that falls due as they recede.', 'Fade - to lose brightness, color, or strength gradually over time and accumulate a duller appearance.', 'Gradient - a slope, typically inclined downward; can also refer metaphorically to decline in intensity or quality.', 'Hibernate - to spend the winter months in a state of reduced activity (in animals); related to accumulation of energy stores before hibernation.', 'Lessen - to decrease in size, extent, or importance over time, leading to an accumulation of lesser amounts.', 'Plummet - to fall rapidly and uncontrollably from a high position; can also refer metaphorically to sudden decline.', 'Subside - to become less intense, violent, or active over time, causing an accumulation of lower energy levels.', 'Slump - a sharp downward turn in business profits or productivity, leading to accumulated losses and setbacks.', 'Wane - to decrease gradually over time; often used for phases such as the moon waning (falling due) from fullness.', 'Wither - to dry up or fade away, usually referring to plants that lose their vitality over time and accumulate withered matter.', "Wilt - a plant's leaves drooping downwards, often indicating a decline in health and quality; can also metaphorically refer to human emotions deteriorating over time.", 'Yield - to produce or give (fruits, crops), but it can also mean to decrease under pressure; if stress continues, yield may accumulate more problems.', 'Wear - as in wear and tear on objects that gradually deteriorate over time due to usage and accumulation of damage.', 'Whither - an old term meaning "to which place?" but can also be used metaphorically, referring to the decline or direction something is falling due.', 'Wilt - as in wilted flowers or plants that have fallen due and accumulated dry matter; it can also refer to emotional weakness over time.', 'Decline - a general term for reducing in size, quality, or value; often associated with falling downwards, leading to an accumulation of lesser amounts.']

['Coin - A small, flat, circular piece of metal used as money.', 'Nickel - A five cent coin made up primarily of nickel and other metals.', 'Penny - The smallest denomination of currency in many countries (e.g., one penny is worth one cent).', 'Dime - A ten cent coin, typically used for making small purchases or as a tip.', 'Quarter - A twenty-five cent coin that can be used to make change for larger bills.', 'Puffballs - Small spherical fungi that may look like coins due to their round shape', 'Monies - Collective noun referring to different types of money or currencies in general.', 'Cash - Physical money in the form of bills and coins used for transactions.', "Pocket change - Small amounts of money kept in one's pocket, often made up of loose coins.", 'Legal tender - A medium of payment recognized by law that can be used to settle public or private debts.', 'Tokens - Non-currency objects that are assigned value and may be used as a form of small change in certain situations.', 'Mintage - The process of producing coins, including the number made available for circulation.', 'Currency notes - Paper bills representing different denominations of money issued by central banks or governments.', 'Banks - Financial institutions where individuals can deposit, withdraw, and exchange currency.', 'Exchange rate - The value of one currency compared to another when converting between them for trade or travel.', 'Change purse/wallet - A small pouch used specifically to carry coins and bills for making change during transactions.', 'Swear jar - An informal, humorous method of collecting spare change with a designated container (not related directly to currency).', 'Penny farthing - An old-fashioned large-wheeled bicycle from the 19th century; not directly related to small change but shares the name with the British penny coin.', 'Slot machines - Gambling devices that require players to insert coins or tokens in order to play a game, often dispensing more coins as winnings.', 'Coin rolls - Pre-packaged containers holding a standard number of coins for easy buying and selling (usually 50 cents worth).']
